title: Qualisys Calqulus Pipeline
description: A document describing calculations to be done on biomechanical data for presentation in a report.

parameter.title: Parameter node
parameter.description: A parameter node defines steps used to calculate a value or a sequence of values. The result is exported to the global scope and exported in the resulting JSON file.

space.title: Space node
space.description: A parameter node defines steps used to calculate a value or a sequence of values. The result is exported to the global scope and exported in the resulting JSON file.

event.title: Event node
event.description: A parameter node defines steps used to calculate a value or a sequence of values. The result is exported to the global scope and exported in the resulting JSON file.

marker.title: Marker node
marker.description: A parameter node defines steps used to calculate a value or a sequence of values. The result is exported to the global scope and exported in the resulting JSON file.

segment.title: Marker node
segment.description: A parameter node defines steps used to calculate a value or a sequence of values. The result is exported to the global scope and exported in the resulting JSON file.

steps.title: Node steps
steps.description: A step node takes an input and some options and outputs a value.

oneOf.title: Step: angle
oneOf.description:
The angle step performs slightly different operation depending on the type and number of inputs.

Note: _For cases where multiple inputs are given of varying lengths, the returning array will be the maximum length and the last value will be repeated for the shorter inputs to fill the gap._

One input: `` Computes the euler angle of the specified segment, in degrees.

Two inputs: (, ) | (, ) Given two segments: Computes the relative (euler) angle between the specified segments, in degrees.

Given two vectors: Computes relative angle between the specified vectors, in radians.

Three inputs: , ,  Computes the angle between the two vectors defined by the specified points (v0 -> v1, v1 -> v2), in radians. The points can be specified as arrays or with named vector signals (ie markers).

Given the inputs v1, v2 and v3, the resulting angle is given by:

angleBetween(v1 - v0, v1 - v2)

Four inputs: , , ,  Computes the angle between the two lines formed by (v0 -> v1, v2 -> v3), in radians. The points can be specified as arrays or with named vector signals (ie markers).

angle.title: angle step
angle.description:
The angle step performs slightly different operation depending on the type and number of inputs.

Note: _For cases where multiple inputs are given of varying lengths, the returning array will be the maximum length and the last value will be repeated for the shorter inputs to fill the gap._

One input: `` Computes the euler angle of the specified segment, in degrees.

Two inputs: (, ) | (, ) Given two segments: Computes the relative (euler) angle between the specified segments, in degrees.

Given two vectors: Computes relative angle between the specified vectors, in radians.

Three inputs: , ,  Computes the angle between the two vectors defined by the specified points (v0 -> v1, v1 -> v2), in radians. The points can be specified as arrays or with named vector signals (ie markers).

Given the inputs v1, v2 and v3, the resulting angle is given by:

angleBetween(v1 - v0, v1 - v2)

Four inputs: , , ,  Computes the angle between the two lines formed by (v0 -> v1, v2 -> v3), in radians. The points can be specified as arrays or with named vector signals (ie markers).

oneOf.title: Step: angularVelocity
oneOf.description:
This step calculates the joint angular velocity based on the textbook Research Methods in Biomechanics (2nd Edition).

You can visit http://www.kwon3d.com/theory/euler/avel.html for more details.

This is different from calculating the first-order derivate of the joint angle because each axis of the joint angle are different from the axes of the segment coordinate systems.

**Please consider which implementation would be correct to use in your instance**.

angularVelocity.title: angularVelocity step
angularVelocity.description:
This step calculates the joint angular velocity based on the textbook Research Methods in Biomechanics (2nd Edition).

You can visit http://www.kwon3d.com/theory/euler/avel.html for more details.

This is different from calculating the first-order derivate of the joint angle because each axis of the joint angle are different from the axes of the segment coordinate systems.

**Please consider which implementation would be correct to use in your instance**.

useRotationOrder.title: angularVelocity > useRotationOrder
useRotationOrder.description:
If set to false it means that the angular velocity between the segment and refernce segment is transformed to be expressed into the resolution coordinate system.

If set to true it means that angular velocity between the segment and refernce segment is transformed to be expressed into the joint coordinate system using the Euler/Cardan sequence.

oneOf.title: Step: jointAngle
oneOf.description: Performs the same computation as angle, but does not handle three or four inputs.

jointAngle.title: jointAngle step
jointAngle.description: Performs the same computation as angle, but does not handle three or four inputs.

oneOf.title: Step: jointAngleVelocity
oneOf.description: Performs the same computation as angularVelocity.

jointAngleVelocity.title: jointAngleVelocity step
jointAngleVelocity.description: Performs the same computation as angularVelocity.

useRotationOrder.title: jointAngleVelocity > useRotationOrder
useRotationOrder.description:
If set to false it means that the angular velocity between the segment and refernce segment is transformed to be expressed into the resolution coordinate system.

If set to true it means that angular velocity between the segment and refernce segment is transformed to be expressed into the joint coordinate system using the Euler/Cardan sequence.

oneOf.title: Step: count
oneOf.description: Counts the number of values in the input, i.e. the number of frames in a series, or the number of values in a scalar or event input.

count.title: count step
count.description: Counts the number of values in the input, i.e. the number of frames in a series, or the number of values in a scalar or event input.

oneOf.title: Step: max
oneOf.description: Outputs the max value of the input.

max.title: max step
max.description: Outputs the max value of the input.

frames.title: max > frames
frames.description: If set to true, this step returns the frame index for the maximum value of the input. If using cycles, it will return a frame per cycle.

oneOf.title: Step: mean
oneOf.description: Outputs the mean value of the input.

mean.title: mean step
mean.description: Outputs the mean value of the input.

oneOf.title: Step: median
oneOf.description: Outputs the minimum value of the input.

median.title: median step
median.description: Outputs the minimum value of the input.

frames.title: median > frames
frames.description: If set to true, this step returns the frame index for the minimum value of the input. If using cycles, it will return a frame per cycle.

oneOf.title: Step: min
oneOf.description: Outputs the median value of the input.

min.title: min step
min.description: Outputs the median value of the input.

oneOf.title: Step: range
oneOf.description: Outputs the range between the minimum and maximum value of the input.

range.title: range step
range.description: Outputs the range between the minimum and maximum value of the input.

oneOf.title: Step: rms
oneOf.description: Outputs the Root Mean Square (root of the average squared deviations) between two arrays.

rms.title: rms step
rms.description: Outputs the Root Mean Square (root of the average squared deviations) between two arrays.

oneOf.title: Step: standardDeviation
oneOf.description: Outputs the standard deviation value of the input.

standardDeviation.title: standardDeviation step
standardDeviation.description: Outputs the standard deviation value of the input.

oneOf.title: Step: standardDeviation
oneOf.description: Outputs the standard deviation value of the input.

stdDev.title: stdDev step
stdDev.description: Outputs the standard deviation value of the input.

oneOf.title: Step: sum
oneOf.description: Outputs the sum of all values of the input.

sum.title: sum step
sum.description: Outputs the sum of all values of the input.

oneOf.title: Step: add
oneOf.description: Adds the input operands.

oneOf.title: Step: divide
oneOf.description: Divides the input operands.

oneOf.title: Step: multiply
oneOf.description: Multiplies the input operands.

oneOf.title: Step: subtract
oneOf.description: Subtracts the input operands.

oneOf.title: Step: distance
oneOf.description:
Accepts marker or segment sequences and calculates the distance between the points (Euclidian norm).

It assumes that the values are comparable by index. If the sequence length differs, the calculation will be done up until the shortest length of the input sequences.

distance.title: distance step
distance.description:
Accepts marker or segment sequences and calculates the distance between the points (Euclidian norm).

It assumes that the values are comparable by index. If the sequence length differs, the calculation will be done up until the shortest length of the input sequences.

oneOf.title: Step: magnitude
oneOf.description: Accepts a vector or a segment sequence and calculates the magnitude of it (Euclidian norm).

magnitude.title: magnitude step
magnitude.description: Accepts a vector or a segment sequence and calculates the magnitude of it (Euclidian norm).

oneOf.title: Step: plane
oneOf.description:
Takes three marker or segment sequences and returns the plane which intersects all three points.

It assumes that the values are comparable by index. If the sequence length differs, the calculation will be done up until the shortest length of the input sequences.

plane.title: plane step
plane.description:
Takes three marker or segment sequences and returns the plane which intersects all three points.

It assumes that the values are comparable by index. If the sequence length differs, the calculation will be done up until the shortest length of the input sequences.

oneOf.title: Step: project
oneOf.description:
Orthogonally projects a point onto a plane and returns the location of the projected point.

Note: *The plane will remain in the space used when creating it, applying a space to the project step will apply the space to the vector / segment, but the plane will be left untouched.*

project.title: project step
project.description:
Orthogonally projects a point onto a plane and returns the location of the projected point.

Note: *The plane will remain in the space used when creating it, applying a space to the project step will apply the space to the vector / segment, but the plane will be left untouched.*

oneOf.title: Step: unitVector
oneOf.description: Calculates the unit vector i.e. the new vector has the same direction of the input vector but its norm equals 1.

unitVector.title: unitVector step
unitVector.description: Calculates the unit vector i.e. the new vector has the same direction of the input vector but its norm equals 1.

oneOf.title: Step: abs
oneOf.description: Outputs the absolute value for each value in the input signal.

abs.title: abs step
abs.description: Outputs the absolute value for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: convert
oneOf.description: For each value of the input, converts it according to the units defined in the from and to options.

convert.title: convert step
convert.description: For each value of the input, converts it according to the units defined in the from and to options.

from.title: convert > from
from.description: Defines the unit to convert from.

to.title: convert > to
to.description: Defines the unit to convert to.

oneOf.title: Step: diff
oneOf.description: Outputs the difference between each value in the input. Since this compares value n with n+1, the output signal will be shorter by one item.

diff.title: diff step
diff.description: Outputs the difference between each value in the input. Since this compares value n with n+1, the output signal will be shorter by one item.

oneOf.title: Step: dotProduct
oneOf.description:
Calculates the dot product between two vectors.

The output length will be equal to the length of the first vector sequence.

The second vector sequence needs to be singular or equal to the first vector sequence in length.

A lone vector in the second input will be used to calculate the dot product between itself and all vectors contained in the first vector sequence.

dotProduct.title: dotProduct step
dotProduct.description:
Calculates the dot product between two vectors.

The output length will be equal to the length of the first vector sequence.

The second vector sequence needs to be singular or equal to the first vector sequence in length.

A lone vector in the second input will be used to calculate the dot product between itself and all vectors contained in the first vector sequence.

oneOf.title: Step: dotProduct
oneOf.description:
Calculates the dot product between two vectors.

The output length will be equal to the length of the first vector sequence.

The second vector sequence needs to be singular or equal to the first vector sequence in length.

A lone vector in the second input will be used to calculate the dot product between itself and all vectors contained in the first vector sequence.

dot.title: dot step
dot.description:
Calculates the dot product between two vectors.

The output length will be equal to the length of the first vector sequence.

The second vector sequence needs to be singular or equal to the first vector sequence in length.

A lone vector in the second input will be used to calculate the dot product between itself and all vectors contained in the first vector sequence.

oneOf.title: Step: gapFill
oneOf.description:
Outputs a resulting signal of the same type as the input signal where gaps are filled using interpolation.

Note: *Gaps at the beginning or end of the signal will not be interpolated.*

gapFill.title: gapFill step
gapFill.description:
Outputs a resulting signal of the same type as the input signal where gaps are filled using interpolation.

Note: *Gaps at the beginning or end of the signal will not be interpolated.*

oneOf.title: Step: integral
oneOf.description: Returns the cumulative integral between neighboring frames in a data series, using the trapezoidal rule. It returns a series by default.

integral.title: integral step
integral.description: Returns the cumulative integral between neighboring frames in a data series, using the trapezoidal rule. It returns a series by default.

scalar.title: integral > scalar
scalar.description: Returns the integral as a single value scalar.

useCycles.title: integral > useCycles
useCycles.description:
If the signal has cycles defined, the integral step will be run separately over each signal, and a list of values are returned, one for each cycle.

To avoid this behaviour, set useCycles to false.

For information on how to set event cycles on a signal, see the eventMask step.

oneOf.title: Step: negate
oneOf.description: Outputs the negated value for each value in the input signal.

negate.title: negate step
negate.description: Outputs the negated value for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: round
oneOf.description:
Outputs a resulting signal of the same type as the input signal where every value is rounded to the specific precision.

The precision is specified as the number of decimal places to include in the result.

round.title: round step
round.description:
Outputs a resulting signal of the same type as the input signal where every value is rounded to the specific precision.

The precision is specified as the number of decimal places to include in the result.

oneOf.title: Step: acceleration
oneOf.description:
Derives the input signal to the second order.

Note: _Due to the temporal nature of this operation, the resulting first and last frames will be null._

acceleration.title: acceleration step
acceleration.description:
Derives the input signal to the second order.

Note: _Due to the temporal nature of this operation, the resulting first and last frames will be null._

oneOf.title: Step: derivative
oneOf.description:
Derives the input signal to the order defined in input 2. If input 2 is not set, the signal is derived to order 1.

Only the first and second order is supported.

Note: _Due to the temporal nature of this operation, the resulting first and last frames will be null._

derivative.title: derivative step
derivative.description:
Derives the input signal to the order defined in input 2. If input 2 is not set, the signal is derived to order 1.

Only the first and second order is supported.

Note: _Due to the temporal nature of this operation, the resulting first and last frames will be null._

oneOf.title: Step: velocity
oneOf.description:
Derives the input signal to the first order.

Note: _Due to the temporal nature of this operation, the resulting first and last frame will be null._

velocity.title: velocity step
velocity.description:
Derives the input signal to the first order.

Note: _Due to the temporal nature of this operation, the resulting first and last frame will be null._

oneOf.title: Step: highpass
oneOf.description: Runs a Butterworth high-pass filter over the input data.

highpass.title: highpass step
highpass.description: Runs a Butterworth high-pass filter over the input data.

extrapolate.title: highpass > extrapolate
extrapolate.description:
Defines how much to add on either side of the series, useful if the filter handles the edges of the series strangely.

Leading and trailing NaN values are removed before extrapolation, i.e., extrapolation begins from the first and last real value. NaN values are then re-inserted in the original places for the output.

iterations.title: highpass > iterations
iterations.description: Defines how many times to apply the filter.

cutoff.title: highpass > cutoff
cutoff.description: Defines around what frequency to limit the filter.

oneOf.title: Step: lowpass
oneOf.description: Runs a Butterworth low-pass filter over the input data.

lowpass.title: lowpass step
lowpass.description: Runs a Butterworth low-pass filter over the input data.

extrapolate.title: lowpass > extrapolate
extrapolate.description:
Defines how much to add on either side of the series, useful if the filter handles the edges of the series strangely.

Leading and trailing NaN values are removed before extrapolation, i.e., extrapolation begins from the first and last real value. NaN values are then re-inserted in the original places for the output.

iterations.title: lowpass > iterations
iterations.description: Defines how many times to apply the filter.

cutoff.title: lowpass > cutoff
cutoff.description: Defines around what frequency to limit the filter.

oneOf.title: Step: acos
oneOf.description: Outputs the arc cosine (or inverse cosine) for each value in the input signal.

acos.title: acos step
acos.description: Outputs the arc cosine (or inverse cosine) for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: asin
oneOf.description: Outputs the arcsine (or inverse sine) for each value in the input signal.

asin.title: asin step
asin.description: Outputs the arcsine (or inverse sine) for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: atan
oneOf.description: Outputs the arctangent (or inverse sine) for each value in the input signal.

atan.title: atan step
atan.description: Outputs the arctangent (or inverse sine) for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: atan2
oneOf.description: Outputs the the angle (in radians) from the X axis to a point for each value in the input signal.

atan2.title: atan2 step
atan2.description: Outputs the the angle (in radians) from the X axis to a point for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: cos
oneOf.description: Outputs the cosine for each value in the input signal.

cos.title: cos step
cos.description: Outputs the cosine for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: cosh
oneOf.description: Outputs the hyperbolic cosine for each value in the input signal.

cosh.title: cosh step
cosh.description: Outputs the hyperbolic cosine for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: cotan
oneOf.description: Outputs the cotangent for each value in the input signal.

cotan.title: cotan step
cotan.description: Outputs the cotangent for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: sin
oneOf.description: Outputs the sine for each value in the input signal.

sin.title: sin step
sin.description: Outputs the sine for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: sinh
oneOf.description: Outputs the hyperbolic sine for each value in the input signal.

sinh.title: sinh step
sinh.description: Outputs the hyperbolic sine for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: tan
oneOf.description: Outputs the tangent for each value in the input signal.

tan.title: tan step
tan.description: Outputs the tangent for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: tanh
oneOf.description: Outputs the hyperbolic tangent for each value in the input signal.

tanh.title: tanh step
tanh.description: Outputs the hyperbolic tangent for each value in the input signal.

oneOf.title: Step: if
oneOf.description:
Runs a logical expression. The return value is determined by the result of the expression, and the then and else options.

The following operators are supported:

  >=

Parentheses can be used to influence the order of evaluation.

Only numbers and single-element arrays can be part of the expression.

if.title: if step
if.description:
Runs a logical expression. The return value is determined by the result of the expression, and the then and else options.

The following operators are supported:

  >=

Parentheses can be used to influence the order of evaluation.

Only numbers and single-element arrays can be part of the expression.

oneOf.title: Step: event
oneOf.description: Imports an event by name.

oneOf.title: Step: import
oneOf.description: Generic import of any input by name.

import.title: import step
import.description: Generic import of any input by name.

oneOf.title: Step: marker
oneOf.description: Imports a marker series by name or creates a new signal with a custom origin.

marker.title: marker step
marker.description: Imports a marker series by name or creates a new signal with a custom origin.

origin.title: marker > origin
origin.description: This option can be used to create a new marker signal, with a custom x, y and z coordinate.

oneOf.title: Step: segment
oneOf.description: Imports a segment series by name.

segment.title: segment step
segment.description: Imports a segment series by name.

oneOf.title: Step: eventDuration
oneOf.description:
This step takes 2 event inputs and outputs an array of durations (in seconds).

Inputs 1 and 2 will be combined into pairs - from values in input 1 to values in input 2.

The duration is calculated using the frame rate from either the "from", or "to" input event.

eventDuration.title: eventDuration step
eventDuration.description:
This step takes 2 event inputs and outputs an array of durations (in seconds).

Inputs 1 and 2 will be combined into pairs - from values in input 1 to values in input 2.

The duration is calculated using the frame rate from either the "from", or "to" input event.

oneOf.title: Step: eventMask
oneOf.description:
This is a step which takes a signal and 2 event inputs and outputs a filtered signal with values only appearing in between the events.

Inputs 2 and 3 will be combined into pairs from values in input 2 to values in input 3.

These pairs can be used to filter the values in input 1.

These event pairs, or cycles are also stored on the resulting signal, which can be used in aggregations to aggregate over event cycles. The signal will keep the cycle information no matter if the signal was truncated or not.

If the signal input is an event, only event frames that is within the span of one of the event pairs will be returned.

The optional parameter replacement will, if set, replace masked values with the given value. If replacement is not set and truncate is true  the masked values will be removed. The replacement property has no effect when the signal input is an event.

If replacement is not set and truncate is false (default behavior), the output signal is untouched, except that the event cycles are annotated on the signal.

eventMask.title: eventMask step
eventMask.description:
This is a step which takes a signal and 2 event inputs and outputs a filtered signal with values only appearing in between the events.

Inputs 2 and 3 will be combined into pairs from values in input 2 to values in input 3.

These pairs can be used to filter the values in input 1.

These event pairs, or cycles are also stored on the resulting signal, which can be used in aggregations to aggregate over event cycles. The signal will keep the cycle information no matter if the signal was truncated or not.

If the signal input is an event, only event frames that is within the span of one of the event pairs will be returned.

The optional parameter replacement will, if set, replace masked values with the given value. If replacement is not set and truncate is true  the masked values will be removed. The replacement property has no effect when the signal input is an event.

If replacement is not set and truncate is false (default behavior), the output signal is untouched, except that the event cycles are annotated on the signal.

replacement.title: eventMask > replacement
replacement.description:
Replacement value to use for masked values. If not set, masked values will be removed from the output signal.

The replacement property has no effect when the signal input is an event.

truncate.title: eventMask > truncate
truncate.description:
Whether or not the signal should be truncated, i.e., if values that were not within an "event pair" should be removed or not.

This will only apply if replacement does not have a value.

oneOf.title: Step: eventTime
oneOf.description:
This step takes an event input and converts each frame value to a time value (in seconds).

The time is calculated using the frame rate from the signal.

eventTime.title: eventTime step
eventTime.description:
This step takes an event input and converts each frame value to a time value (in seconds).

The time is calculated using the frame rate from the signal.

oneOf.title: Step: refineEvent
oneOf.description:
This step allows you to easily pick out frames from an event only when they appear in a specific sequence of other events.

The main input of this step is the event you want to select frames from.

The required option sequence defines a sequence of events to happen in order. This option requires at least one instance of the main input event (otherwise, no event would be able to be picked from the sequence).

Multiple instances of the main input event can be supplied to the sequence to enable more complex patterns of events.

The optional option exclude defines events that cannot occur in a sequence. If it does, the sequence is invalidated, meaning no events will be picked from this sequence.

The exclude option cannot contain any signals defined in the sequence option.

The optional option cyclic defines whether or not the sequence should be treated as cyclic, i.e., if the sequence starts and ends with the same events, those events are included in the next "match-finding" iteration of the sequence. This is useful for refining event cycles where the end event is the start event of the next cycle.

The cyclic option is true by default and has to be explicitly set to false to disable.

refineEvent.title: refineEvent step
refineEvent.description:
This step allows you to easily pick out frames from an event only when they appear in a specific sequence of other events.

The main input of this step is the event you want to select frames from.

The required option sequence defines a sequence of events to happen in order. This option requires at least one instance of the main input event (otherwise, no event would be able to be picked from the sequence).

Multiple instances of the main input event can be supplied to the sequence to enable more complex patterns of events.

The optional option exclude defines events that cannot occur in a sequence. If it does, the sequence is invalidated, meaning no events will be picked from this sequence.

The exclude option cannot contain any signals defined in the sequence option.

The optional option cyclic defines whether or not the sequence should be treated as cyclic, i.e., if the sequence starts and ends with the same events, those events are included in the next "match-finding" iteration of the sequence. This is useful for refining event cycles where the end event is the start event of the next cycle.

The cyclic option is true by default and has to be explicitly set to false to disable.

sequence.title: refineEvent > sequence
sequence.description: A sequence of events. This must include at least one instance of the main input event.

exclude.title: refineEvent > exclude
exclude.description: Event(s) that will invalidate an event sequence if found within it.

cyclic.title: refineEvent > cyclic
cyclic.description: Whether or not to treat sequences as cyclic (true as default).

oneOf.title: Step: peakFinder
oneOf.description:
Find peaks inside a signal based on peak properties.

At first, it will detect any peak-like features in the signal. If any of the options distance, height, prominence, or width is defined, it will use those properties to filter out peaks that match the criteria.

As a last step, if the sequence option is used, it will match the peaks against a sequence to return a subset of the peaks.

As a general rule, the peakFinder step is sensitive to noise in the data, so if noise is expected, first run the data through a low-pass filter.

Based on the SciPy find_peaks function.

peakFinder.title: peakFinder step
peakFinder.description:
Find peaks inside a signal based on peak properties.

At first, it will detect any peak-like features in the signal. If any of the options distance, height, prominence, or width is defined, it will use those properties to filter out peaks that match the criteria.

As a last step, if the sequence option is used, it will match the peaks against a sequence to return a subset of the peaks.

As a general rule, the peakFinder step is sensitive to noise in the data, so if noise is expected, first run the data through a low-pass filter.

Based on the SciPy find_peaks function.

distance.title: peakFinder > distance
distance.description:
Required minimal horizontal distance (>= 1) in samples between neighbouring peaks.

Smaller peaks are removed first until the condition is fulfilled for all remaining peaks.

height.title: peakFinder > height
height.description: Required height of peaks. Either a number or a 2-element array. The first element is always interpreted as the minimal and the second, if supplied, as the maximal required height.

prominence.title: peakFinder > prominence
prominence.description: Required prominence of peaks. Either a number or a 2-element array. The first element is always interpreted as the minimal and the second, if supplied, as the maximal required prominence.

relHeight.title: peakFinder > relHeight
relHeight.description:
Used for calculation of the peaks width, thus it is only used if width is given.

Chooses the relative height at which the peak width is measured as a percentage of its prominence. 1.0 calculates the width of the peak at its lowest contour line while 0.5 evaluates at half the prominence height. Must be at least 0.

sequence.title: peakFinder > sequence
sequence.description:
Allows to classify peaks using a pattern and select peaks from the pattern to use as the output.

See below for further information.

ranges.title: peakFinder > sequence > ranges
ranges.description:
Classification of the peak heights. This option expects a string consisting of 1-character labels separated by a boundary value.

The boundary values represent a percentage between 0  100 which defined the end of the previous label's range and the beginning of the next label's range.

The entire range 0  100 represents the difference between the lowest peak and the highest peak. All peaks will be somewhere in this range, and the ranges option allows you to customize how the peaks are labelled.

The default ranges value is: L 50 H. This labels the peaks that end up in the bottom 50% of the peak heights as L, and the remaining top 50% as H.

The syntax, L 50 H, is equivalent to writing 0 L 50 H 100.

The outer boundaries 0 and 100 is assumed though and are not required.

If you would like to classify the peaks into three groups, the bottom 25% as L, the top 25% and H, and anything in between as M, you can supply the following string: L 25 M 75 H.

The labels used should each be 1 character long, but can be whatever you want as long as it corresponds to the pattern used in the pattern option.

pattern.title: peakFinder > sequence > pattern
pattern.description:
A pattern describing a sequence of classified peak heights using the labels defined in the ranges option.

If you have supplied the ranges string L 50 H, and you want to find the following sequence of peaks: "a low peak followed by a low peak followed by a high peak, you can define the pattern as LLH.

Each matching pattern sequence is stored and the pattern indices in keep determines which of the peaks that are returned.

keep.title: peakFinder > sequence > keep
keep.description:
An array of indices from the pattern labels to keep in the output. The index is zero-based, i.e., the first item in the sequence pattern is 0, the last in the sequence is the (length of the pattern) - 1.

If the pattern was defined as LLH and we wanted to keep only the first (low) peak in each matching sequence, we would set keep to [0].

Conversely if we wanted to keep the last (high) peak in each sequence, the keep should be [2].

To keep both the first and last peaks in the sequence, the keep option should be set to [0, 2].

Peaks in the sequence pattern not indexed by keep will be ignored in the output.

width.title: peakFinder > width
width.description:
Required width of peaks in samples. Either a number or a
2-element array. The first element is always interpreted as the minimal and the second, if supplied, as the maximal required width.

window.title: peakFinder > window
window.description:
Used for calculation of the peaks prominences, thus it is only used if one of the arguments prominence or width is given.

A window length in samples that optionally limits the evaluated area for each peak to a subset of x. The peak is always placed in the middle of the window therefore the given length is rounded up to the next odd integer. This parameter can speed up the calculation.

oneOf.title: Step: threshold
oneOf.description:
This step will register an event for every frame where the signal passes the specified threshold value.

By default, an event is registered when the signal crosses the threshold in either an ascending or descending direction.

By configuring the direction option, you can specify a certain direction that will trigger the event; up (ascending) or down (descending).

threshold.title: threshold step
threshold.description:
This step will register an event for every frame where the signal passes the specified threshold value.

By default, an event is registered when the signal crosses the threshold in either an ascending or descending direction.

By configuring the direction option, you can specify a certain direction that will trigger the event; up (ascending) or down (descending).

direction.title: threshold > direction
direction.description: The direction of crossing the threshold to record.

oneOf.title: Step: concatenate
oneOf.description: The concatenate step takes any number of inputs (at least 2) of the same (or equivalent) types and appends the values into one output. This will be done on each component, if they exist.

concatenate.title: concatenate step
concatenate.description: The concatenate step takes any number of inputs (at least 2) of the same (or equivalent) types and appends the values into one output. This will be done on each component, if they exist.

oneOf.title: Step: vector
oneOf.description:
The vector step takes one or three inputs and outputs a vector sequence signal.

If given three numeric or 1-dimensional series inputs, each input will be assigned to the x, y, and z components, respectively.

Alternatively, if only one input is given and it contains at least three components, the first three components will be used to construct the vector sequence.

If the inputs have different lengths, the output signal will be the length of the longest input and shorter inputs will be padded with NaN values.

vector.title: vector step
vector.description:
The vector step takes one or three inputs and outputs a vector sequence signal.

If given three numeric or 1-dimensional series inputs, each input will be assigned to the x, y, and z components, respectively.

Alternatively, if only one input is given and it contains at least three components, the first three components will be used to construct the vector sequence.

If the inputs have different lengths, the output signal will be the length of the longest input and shorter inputs will be padded with NaN values.

where.title: Measurement filtering
where.description:
When importing a signal or defining an output node, you can specify a measurement from which the signal should be imported  or for which measurement an output node should run.

You can filter measurements by name and by field values and you can use wildcard characters `*` to formulate patterns to match partial values. The matching of values is case-insensitive.

When using a measurement filter, a list of matching measurements is created. By specifying the `index` option, you can define which of the matching measurements should apply.

index.title: Index filter
index.description: Out of a number of matching measurements, pick the nth match. Either a 1-based index, or the values `first` or `last` to select the first or last match, respectively.

fields.title: Field filter
fields.description: Target a measurement by a field value.

set.title: Output set
set.description:
Used to specify which _set_ the exported parameter will use. In most cases, this will be either `left` or `right`.

If not set, the JSON output will use set: null.

spaceOrigin.title: Origin
spaceOrigin.description: Sets the origin of a custom coordinate system.

spacePrimaryAxis.title: Primary axis
spacePrimaryAxis.description:
Sets the primary axis of a custom coordinate system. The primary axis of the custom coordinate system will always be a unit vector with the same direction as this vector.
				
If more than one vectors is given, for example [myMarker1, myMarker2], the vector difference between the first two vectors is used as the primary axis.

spaceSecondaryAxis.title: Secondary axis
spaceSecondaryAxis.description:
Sets the secondary axis of a custom coordinate system. The actual secondary axis of the custom coordinate system might differ from the vector specified, since the secondary axis must be a unit vector perpendicular to the primary axis.
				
If more than one vectors is given, for example [myMarker1, myMarker2], the vector difference between the first two vectors is used as the secondary axis.

spaceOrder.title: Order
spaceOrder.description:
Defines what axis the primary and secondary axis corresponds to. The first letter defines the name of the primary axis, and the second letter defines the name of the secondary axis.
				
Possible values:
xy - Primary axis: x, secondary axis: y
yx - Primary axis: y, secondary axis: x
xz - Primary axis: x, secondary axis: z
yz - Primary axis: y, secondary axis: z
zy - Primary axis: z, secondary axis: y

spaceAlignWithSegment.title: Align with segment
spaceAlignWithSegment.description:
Used to create a space that aligns with the specified segment. The resulting space will be rotated in 90 degree increments relative to the world space.

The rotation is based on the average orientation of the segment during a measurement.

segment.title: Segment to align to
segment.description:
Used to create a space that aligns with the specified segment. The resulting space will be rotated in 90 degree increments relative to the world space.

The rotation is based on the average orientation of the segment during a measurement.

Parameter Node.title: Parameter node
Parameter Node.description: A parameter node defines steps used to calculate a value or a sequence of values. The result is exported to the global scope and exported in the resulting JSON file.

globalOption export.title: export (global option)
globalOption export.description:
If this option is set, the result of this step will be exposed on the global scope, as well as being exported to the resulting JSON file.

The value of this option will be the name of the exported data and can be used to load the resulting data in other steps.
globalOption export.name: export

globalOption output.title: output (global option)
globalOption output.description:
If this option is set, the result of this step will be exposed on the local scope.

The value of this option will be the name of the output data and can be used to load the resulting data in other steps within the same output node.

You can also use the short-form "arrow syntax" to define an output.
globalOption output.name: output

globalOption set.title: set (global option)
globalOption set.description:
Used to specify which set the exported parameter will use. In most cases, this will be either left or right.

This option is only used in two cases; where there is also an export option set, or on the last step in a list. In the latter case, the step's set is used only if there's no set defined on the parent output node.

If this option is not set, the JSON output will use set: null.
globalOption set.name: set

globalOption space.title: space (global option)
globalOption space.description:
This option lets you reference a space where you want the input data for the step to be translated into.

All named inputs will automatically be converted.

NOTE: This is not yet implemented for segments.
globalOption space.name: space

categoryOption Angle project.title: project (Angle category option)
categoryOption Angle project.description:
If set to a string, the angle will be calculated in two dimensions on the specified coordinate plane by ignoring the component of the input signals which is not part of the plane.

Using a PlaneSequence, projects the input vectors on the provided plane.

Note: _The projection is only applied for vector-based angles and is ignored when calculating joint angles._
categoryOption Angle project.name: project

categoryOption Angle rotationOrder.title: rotationOrder (Angle category option)
categoryOption Angle rotationOrder.description:
The rotation order to use for calculating the Euler angle. Possible rotation orders are:

Cardan sequence: XYZ YZX ZXY XZY YXZ ZYX

Euler sequence: XYX XZX YXY YZY ZXZ ZYZ
categoryOption Angle rotationOrder.name: rotationOrder

categoryOption Angle unwrap.title: unwrap (Angle category option)
categoryOption Angle unwrap.description:
When set to true, an event, or a numeric value, the unwrap option shifts the angle phases in order to achieve a continuous curve, i.e., it tries to detect when an angle crosses over its available range (-PI to PI for radians, -180 to 180 degrees).

This allows for tracking angles on movements that goes outside of the typical angle range.

To do this, it looks for jumps between consecutive angles. If the jump is greater than a threshold of half the range (PI for radians, 180 for degrees), the angle is shifted by adding multiples of of the range until the jump no longer crosses the threshold.

The unwrap algorithm is run over all available components.

If set to true or 0, the algorithm aligns the unwrap to the start of the sequence. I.e., it assumes the first frame is correct in being within the original range and the following angles are moved to follow suit.

If set to an Event or a Number, the algorithm will assume that the corresponding frame is correct in being within the original range. All other angles will be shifted to follow suit. This enables tracking a rotational movement where the angle for a specific event is intended to be within the standard range (-PI to PI for radians, -180 to 180 degrees).

IF a supplied event has more than one instance, the first instance is used.

Note: _The unwrap algorithm is sensitive to noise, which may introduce unexpected artifacts. Please consider filtering the signal(s) before calculating its angle using unwrap._
categoryOption Angle unwrap.name: unwrap

categoryOption Aggregation useCycles.title: useCycles (Aggregation category option)
categoryOption Aggregation useCycles.description:
If the signal has cycles defined, the aggregation will be run separately over each signal, and a list of values are returned, one for each cycle.

To avoid this behaviour, set useCycles to false.

For information on how to set event cycles on a signal, see the eventMask step.
categoryOption Aggregation useCycles.name: useCycles

categoryOption Arithmetic frameSequenceO.title: frameSequenceOrder (Arithmetic category option)
categoryOption Arithmetic frameSequenceO.description:
If set to any value but none, the input signals will pass through a function which returns a list of signals where each value is from a frame greater than or equal to the frame of the corresponding value from the preceding Signal.

If set to forward, it will start from the first value of the first (leftmost) input signal (operand) and the algorithm will look at subsequent operands (to the right) one "row" at a time.

Conversely, if set to reverse, the event sequencing uses the reverse order of operands and goes from right to left.

If a full "row" of values could not be matched, it is not included in the result, i.e., all operands will be of the same length.

This is useful, for example, when calculating the distance between two signals at a certain event.

The function will only apply if all input signals have applied a Frames filter, otherwise the signals are left untouched.

Example

subtract: [LeftFoot.y@LFS, RightFoot.y@RFS]            frameSequenceOrder: reverse

_Creates an event sequence from the inputs, starting from the second operand (RFS event) and creates event pairs RFS -> LFS out of the values. It then subtracts each frame from the RightFoot from the corresponding LeftFoot frame._

_If frameSequenceOrder had been set to forward, it would have created pairs going from LFS -> RFS instead._

_Using the frameSequenceOrder option ensures that the operands starts with the intended event and that both operands have the same length._
categoryOption Arithmetic frameSequenceO.name: frameSequenceOrder
